title: 107_hr1181
content: The "Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 2001" allows for a credit for health insurance costs of previously uninsured individuals under section 25B of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 2001" provides a tax credit for individuals who pay for qualified health insurance coverage for themselves, their spouse, and dependents. The credit is limited to $1,500 per eligible coverage month for each individual. The tax credit under the "Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 2001" is limited to $1,500 per eligible coverage month for each individual. A taxpayer can only take into account up to 2 individuals, with a special rule for married individuals who do not file a joint return. The tax credit for eligible coverage months under the "Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 2001" is limited to $1,500 per individual. Married individuals who do not file a joint return have a special rule where only one individual can be taken into account under this subsection. An eligible coverage month is defined as a month where the individual is covered by qualified health insurance with premiums paid by the taxpayer for at least a 12-month period before that month. The tax credit for eligible coverage months is limited to $1,500 per individual. An eligible coverage month is when the individual is covered by qualified health insurance with premiums paid by the taxpayer for at least a 12-month period. The credit is reduced based on adjusted gross income. The tax credit for eligible coverage months is limited to $1,500 per individual and is reduced based on adjusted gross income. The reduction amount is calculated based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income compared to a specified dollar amount. The tax credit for eligible coverage months is limited to $1,500 per individual and is reduced based on modified adjusted gross income. The applicable dollar amount is $60,000 for coverage of more than 1 individual and $30,000 otherwise. Amounts not multiples of $10 are rounded down. Qualified health insurance coverage for more than one individual is limited to $30,000, with marital status determined under section 7703. Qualified health insurance excludes coverage of excepted benefits. Qualified health insurance refers to medical care insurance, excluding coverage of excepted benefits. It does not include insurance where less than 50 percent of the cost is paid by the taxpayer. Additionally, no credit is allowed for amounts paid under specific government-provided programs. The section outlines that amounts paid under certain government programs are not eligible for the credit. Coverage under specified provisions is considered as coverage under qualified health insurance. Special rules state that no credit is allowed if the amount paid for qualified health insurance is used for other deductions. The section specifies that the credit is not allowed if amounts paid for qualified health insurance are used for other deductions. No credit is given to dependents if a deduction is allowable to another taxpayer for the same taxable year. Starting in 2002, dollar amounts in specific subsections will be increased annually based on the cost-of-living adjustment. If the adjusted amount is not a multiple of $100, it will be rounded down. Section 3 introduces a deduction for qualified health insurance costs of employees and self-employed individuals. In general, individuals can deduct the amount paid for qualified health insurance coverage for themselves, their spouse, and dependents. Special rules apply, such as not double-counting insurance payments for other deductions and not allowing the deduction for self-employment tax purposes. These amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2001. The deduction for qualified health insurance costs is not considered in an individual's net earnings from self-employment.
